trans-unit.source: Service Fabric Web API Services with OWIN self-host | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric Web API Services with OWIN self-host | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This Service Fabric article explains how to implement service communication using ASP.NET Web API with OWIN self-hosting in Reliable Services.
trans-unit.target: This Service Fabric article explains how to implement service communication using ASP.NET Web API with OWIN self-hosting in Reliable Services.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric puts the power in your hands when deciding how you want your services to communicate with users and with each other.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric puts the power in your hands when deciding how you want your services to communicate with users and with each other.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial focuses on implementing service communication using ASP.NET Web API with OWIN self-hosting in Service Fabric's Reliable Services API.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial focuses on implementing service communication using ASP.NET Web API with OWIN self-hosting in Service Fabric's Reliable Services API.

trans-unit.source: We'll go in depth into the Reliable Services pluggable communication API and show you step-by-step how to set up a custom communication listener for you service with Web API used as an example.
trans-unit.target: We'll go in depth into the Reliable Services pluggable communication API and show you step-by-step how to set up a custom communication listener for you service with Web API used as an example.

trans-unit.source: To see a complete example of a Web API communication listener, check out the <linkText>Service Fabric WebApplication sample on GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see a complete example of a Web API communication listener, check out the <linkText>Service Fabric WebApplication sample on GitHub</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET Web API is a popular and powerful framework for building HTTP APIs on top of the .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET Web API is a popular and powerful framework for building HTTP APIs on top of the .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: Head on over to <linkText>www.asp.net/webapi</linkText><title></title> to learn more about Web API if you're not familiar with it already.
trans-unit.target: Head on over to <linkText>www.asp.net/webapi</linkText><title></title> to learn more about Web API if you're not familiar with it already.

trans-unit.source: Web API in Service Fabric is the same ASP.NET Web API you know and love.
trans-unit.target: Web API in Service Fabric is the same ASP.NET Web API you know and love.

trans-unit.source: The difference is in how you host a Web API application (hint: you won't be using IIS).
trans-unit.target: The difference is in how you host a Web API application (hint: you won't be using IIS).

trans-unit.source: To better understand the difference, let's break it into two parts:
trans-unit.target: To better understand the difference, let's break it into two parts:

trans-unit.source: The Web API application (your controllers, models, etc.)
trans-unit.target: The Web API application (your controllers, models, etc.)

trans-unit.source: The host (the web server, usually IIS)
trans-unit.target: The host (the web server, usually IIS)

trans-unit.source: The Web API application itself doesn't change here - it's no different from Web API applications you may have written in the past, and you should be able to simply move most of your application code right over.
trans-unit.target: The Web API application itself doesn't change here - it's no different from Web API applications you may have written in the past, and you should be able to simply move most of your application code right over.

trans-unit.source: Hosting the application may be a little different from what you're used to if you're used to hosting on IIS.
trans-unit.target: Hosting the application may be a little different from what you're used to if you're used to hosting on IIS.

trans-unit.source: But before we get into the hosting part, let's start with the more familiar part: the Web API application.
trans-unit.target: But before we get into the hosting part, let's start with the more familiar part: the Web API application.

trans-unit.source: Start by creating a new application, with a single stateless service, in Visual Studio 2015:
trans-unit.target: Start by creating a new application, with a single stateless service, in Visual Studio 2015:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new Service Fabric application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new Service Fabric application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a single stateless service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a single stateless service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This gives us an empty Stateless Service that will host the Web API application.
trans-unit.target: This gives us an empty Stateless Service that will host the Web API application.

trans-unit.source: We're going to set the application up from scratch to see how it's all put together.
trans-unit.target: We're going to set the application up from scratch to see how it's all put together.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to pull in some NuGet packages for Web API.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to pull in some NuGet packages for Web API.

trans-unit.source: The package we want to use is Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.OwinSelfHost.
trans-unit.target: The package we want to use is Microsoft.AspNet.WebApi.OwinSelfHost.

trans-unit.source: This package includes all the necessary Web API packages and the host packages - this will be important later.
trans-unit.target: This package includes all the necessary Web API packages and the host packages - this will be important later.

trans-unit.source: With the packages installed, we can begin building out the basic Web API project structure.
trans-unit.target: With the packages installed, we can begin building out the basic Web API project structure.

trans-unit.source: If you've used Web API, the project structure should look very familiar.
trans-unit.target: If you've used Web API, the project structure should look very familiar.

trans-unit.source: Start by creating the basic Web API directories:
trans-unit.target: Start by creating the basic Web API directories:

trans-unit.source: App_Start
trans-unit.target: App_Start

trans-unit.source: Controllers
trans-unit.target: Controllers

trans-unit.source: Models
trans-unit.target: Models

trans-unit.source: Add the basic Web API configuration classes in the App_Start directory:
trans-unit.target: Add the basic Web API configuration classes in the App_Start directory:

trans-unit.source: FormatterConfig.cs
trans-unit.target: FormatterConfig.cs

trans-unit.source: RouteConfig.cs
trans-unit.target: RouteConfig.cs

trans-unit.source: Add a default controller in the Controllers directory:
trans-unit.target: Add a default controller in the Controllers directory:

trans-unit.source: DefaultController.cs
trans-unit.target: DefaultController.cs

trans-unit.source: Finally, add a Startup class at the project root to register the routing, formatters, and any other configuration setup.
trans-unit.target: Finally, add a Startup class at the project root to register the routing, formatters, and any other configuration setup.

trans-unit.source: This is also where Web API plugs in to the host, which will be revisited again later.
trans-unit.target: This is also where Web API plugs in to the host, which will be revisited again later.

trans-unit.source: While setting up the Startup class, create an interface called IOwinAppBuilder for the Startup class that defines the Configuration method.
trans-unit.target: While setting up the Startup class, create an interface called IOwinAppBuilder for the Startup class that defines the Configuration method.

trans-unit.source: Although not technically required for Web API to work, it will allow more flexible use of the Startup class later.
trans-unit.target: Although not technically required for Web API to work, it will allow more flexible use of the Startup class later.

trans-unit.source: Startup.cs
trans-unit.target: Startup.cs

trans-unit.source: IOwinAppBuilder.cs
trans-unit.target: IOwinAppBuilder.cs

trans-unit.source: That's it for the application part.
trans-unit.target: That's it for the application part.

trans-unit.source: At this point we've just set up the basic Web API project layout.
trans-unit.target: At this point we've just set up the basic Web API project layout.

trans-unit.source: Compared to Web API projects you may have written in the past or to the basic Web API template, it shouldn't look much different so far.
trans-unit.target: Compared to Web API projects you may have written in the past or to the basic Web API template, it shouldn't look much different so far.

trans-unit.source: Your business logic goes in the controllers and models as usual.
trans-unit.target: Your business logic goes in the controllers and models as usual.

trans-unit.source: Now what do we do about hosting so we can actually run it?
trans-unit.target: Now what do we do about hosting so we can actually run it?

trans-unit.source: In Service Fabric, your service runs in a service host process - an executable that runs your service code.
trans-unit.target: In Service Fabric, your service runs in a service host process - an executable that runs your service code.

trans-unit.source: When writing a service using the Reliable Services API, and in fact in most cases when you're writing a service on Service Fabric in .NET, your service project just compiles to an .EXE that registers your service type and runs your code.
trans-unit.target: When writing a service using the Reliable Services API, and in fact in most cases when you're writing a service on Service Fabric in .NET, your service project just compiles to an .EXE that registers your service type and runs your code.

trans-unit.source: In fact, if you open Program.cs in the stateless service project, you should see:
trans-unit.target: In fact, if you open Program.cs in the stateless service project, you should see:

trans-unit.source: If that looks suspiciously like the entry point to a console application, that's because it is:
trans-unit.target: If that looks suspiciously like the entry point to a console application, that's because it is:

trans-unit.source: Details about the service host process and service registration is beyond the scope of this article, but it's important to know for now that your service code is running in its own process.
trans-unit.target: Details about the service host process and service registration is beyond the scope of this article, but it's important to know for now that your service code is running in its own process.

trans-unit.source: Given that your Web API application code is hosted in its own process, how do we hook it up to a web server?
trans-unit.target: Given that your Web API application code is hosted in its own process, how do we hook it up to a web server?

trans-unit.source: Enter <linkText>OWIN</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Enter <linkText>OWIN</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: OWIN is simply a contract between .NET web applications and web servers.
trans-unit.target: OWIN is simply a contract between .NET web applications and web servers.

trans-unit.source: Traditionally with ASP.NET - up to MVC 5 - the web application was tightly coupled to IIS through System.Web.
trans-unit.target: Traditionally with ASP.NET - up to MVC 5 - the web application was tightly coupled to IIS through System.Web.

trans-unit.source: However, Web API implements OWIN, which allows you to write a web application that is decoupled from the web server that hosts it.
trans-unit.target: However, Web API implements OWIN, which allows you to write a web application that is decoupled from the web server that hosts it.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to use a self-host OWIN web server that you can start in your own process, which fits perfectly in the Service Fabric hosting model we just described.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to use a self-host OWIN web server that you can start in your own process, which fits perfectly in the Service Fabric hosting model we just described.

trans-unit.source: In this article, we'll use Katana as the OWIN host for the Web API application.
trans-unit.target: In this article, we'll use Katana as the OWIN host for the Web API application.

trans-unit.source: Katana is an open-source OWIN host implementation.
trans-unit.target: Katana is an open-source OWIN host implementation.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Katana, head over to the <linkText>Katana site</linkText><title></title>, and for a quick overview of how to use Katana to self-host Web API, check out this article on how to <linkText>Use OWIN to Self-Host ASP.NET Web API 2</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Katana, head over to the <linkText>Katana site</linkText><title></title>, and for a quick overview of how to use Katana to self-host Web API, check out this article on how to <linkText>Use OWIN to Self-Host ASP.NET Web API 2</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Reliable Services API provides two entry points for your business logic:
trans-unit.target: The Reliable Services API provides two entry points for your business logic:

trans-unit.source: An open-ended entry point method where you can begin executing any workload you want, intended mainly for long-running compute workloads:
trans-unit.target: An open-ended entry point method where you can begin executing any workload you want, intended mainly for long-running compute workloads:

trans-unit.source: A communication entry point where you can plug in your communication stack of choice:
trans-unit.target: A communication entry point where you can plug in your communication stack of choice:

trans-unit.source: The web server - and any other communication stack you may use in the future, such as WebSockets - should use the ICommunicationListener interface to correctly integrate with the system.
trans-unit.target: The web server - and any other communication stack you may use in the future, such as WebSockets - should use the ICommunicationListener interface to correctly integrate with the system.

trans-unit.source: The reasons for this will become more apparent in the following steps.
trans-unit.target: The reasons for this will become more apparent in the following steps.

trans-unit.source: First create a class called OwinCommunicationListener that implements ICommunicationListener:
trans-unit.target: First create a class called OwinCommunicationListener that implements ICommunicationListener:

trans-unit.source: OwinCommunicationListener.cs:
trans-unit.target: OwinCommunicationListener.cs:

trans-unit.source: The ICommunicationListener interface provides 4 methods to manage a communication listener for your service:
trans-unit.target: The ICommunicationListener interface provides 4 methods to manage a communication listener for your service:

trans-unit.source: Initialize: this is typically where you set up the address that the service will be listening on.
trans-unit.target: Initialize: this is typically where you set up the address that the service will be listening on.

trans-unit.source: For the web server, this is where the URL is set up.
trans-unit.target: For the web server, this is where the URL is set up.

trans-unit.source: OpenAsync: start listening for requests.
trans-unit.target: OpenAsync: start listening for requests.

trans-unit.source: CloseAsync: stop listening for requests, finish any in-flight requests, and shut down gracefully.
trans-unit.target: CloseAsync: stop listening for requests, finish any in-flight requests, and shut down gracefully.

trans-unit.source: Abort: cancel everything and stop immediately.
trans-unit.target: Abort: cancel everything and stop immediately.

trans-unit.source: To get started, add private class members for a URL path prefix and the Startup class that was created earlier.
trans-unit.target: To get started, add private class members for a URL path prefix and the Startup class that was created earlier.

trans-unit.source: These will be initialized through the constructor and used later when setting up the listening URL.
trans-unit.target: These will be initialized through the constructor and used later when setting up the listening URL.

trans-unit.source: Also add private class members to save the listening address and the server handle that are created during initialization and later when the server is started, respectively.
trans-unit.target: Also add private class members to save the listening address and the server handle that are created during initialization and later when the server is started, respectively.

trans-unit.source: The web server URL will be set up here.
trans-unit.target: The web server URL will be set up here.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you need a couple pieces of information:
trans-unit.target: To do this, you need a couple pieces of information:

trans-unit.source: A URL path prefix.
trans-unit.target: A URL path prefix.

trans-unit.source: Although optional, it's good to set this up now so you can safely host multiple web services in your application.
trans-unit.target: Although optional, it's good to set this up now so you can safely host multiple web services in your application.

trans-unit.source: A port.
trans-unit.target: A port.

trans-unit.source: Before we grab a port for the web server, it's important to understand that Service Fabric provides an application layer that acts as a buffer between your application and the underlying operating system that it runs on.
trans-unit.target: Before we grab a port for the web server, it's important to understand that Service Fabric provides an application layer that acts as a buffer between your application and the underlying operating system that it runs on.

trans-unit.source: As such, Service Fabric provides a way to configure endpoints for your services.
trans-unit.target: As such, Service Fabric provides a way to configure endpoints for your services.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric takes care of making sure the endpoint is available for your service to use so that you don't have to configure it yourself with the underlying OS environment.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric takes care of making sure the endpoint is available for your service to use so that you don't have to configure it yourself with the underlying OS environment.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to easily host your Service Fabric application in different environments without having to make any changes to your application (for example, you can host the same application in Azure or in your own data center).
trans-unit.target: This allows you to easily host your Service Fabric application in different environments without having to make any changes to your application (for example, you can host the same application in Azure or in your own data center).

trans-unit.source: Configure an HTTP endpoint in PackageRoot\ServiceManifest.xml:
trans-unit.target: Configure an HTTP endpoint in PackageRoot\ServiceManifest.xml:

trans-unit.source: This step is important because the service host process runs under restricted credentials (Network Service on Windows), which means your service won't have access to set up an HTTP endpoint on its own.
trans-unit.target: This step is important because the service host process runs under restricted credentials (Network Service on Windows), which means your service won't have access to set up an HTTP endpoint on its own.

trans-unit.source: By using the endpoint configuration, Service Fabric knows to set up the proper ACL for the URL that the service will listen on while providing a standard place to configure endpoints.
trans-unit.target: By using the endpoint configuration, Service Fabric knows to set up the proper ACL for the URL that the service will listen on while providing a standard place to configure endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Back in OwinCommunicationListener.cs, get the endpoint information in the Initialize method to get the port.
trans-unit.target: Back in OwinCommunicationListener.cs, get the endpoint information in the Initialize method to get the port.

trans-unit.source: Create the URL that the service will listen on and save it to the class member variable created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Create the URL that the service will listen on and save it to the class member variable created earlier.

trans-unit.source: This will be used in OpenAsync to start the web server.
trans-unit.target: This will be used in OpenAsync to start the web server.

trans-unit.source: Note that "http://+" is used here.
trans-unit.target: Note that "http://+" is used here.

trans-unit.source: This is to make sure the web server is listening on all available addresses, including localhost, FQDN, and the machine IP.
trans-unit.target: This is to make sure the web server is listening on all available addresses, including localhost, FQDN, and the machine IP.

trans-unit.source: OpenAsync is called by the platform after Initialize.
trans-unit.target: OpenAsync is called by the platform after Initialize.

trans-unit.source: This is where you use the address that was created in Initialize to open the web server.
trans-unit.target: This is where you use the address that was created in Initialize to open the web server.

trans-unit.source: Implementing OpenAsync is one of the most important reasons why the web server (or any communication stack) is implemented as an ICommunicationListener rather than just opening it directly from RunAsync() in the Service.
trans-unit.target: Implementing OpenAsync is one of the most important reasons why the web server (or any communication stack) is implemented as an ICommunicationListener rather than just opening it directly from RunAsync() in the Service.

trans-unit.source: The return value from OpenAsync is the address that the web server is listening on.
trans-unit.target: The return value from OpenAsync is the address that the web server is listening on.

trans-unit.source: When this address is returned to the system, it registers the address with the service.
trans-unit.target: When this address is returned to the system, it registers the address with the service.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric provides an API that allows clients or other services to then ask for this address by service name.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric provides an API that allows clients or other services to then ask for this address by service name.

trans-unit.source: This is important because the service address is not static as services are moved around in the cluster for resource balancing and availability purposes.
trans-unit.target: This is important because the service address is not static as services are moved around in the cluster for resource balancing and availability purposes.

trans-unit.source: This is the mechanism that allows clients to resolve the listening address for a service.
trans-unit.target: This is the mechanism that allows clients to resolve the listening address for a service.

trans-unit.source: With that in mind, OpenAsync starts the web server and return the address it's listening on.
trans-unit.target: With that in mind, OpenAsync starts the web server and return the address it's listening on.

trans-unit.source: Note that it listens on "http://+", but before returning the address, the "+" is replaced with the IP or FQDN of the node it is currently on.
trans-unit.target: Note that it listens on "http://+", but before returning the address, the "+" is replaced with the IP or FQDN of the node it is currently on.

trans-unit.source: The reason for this is that this address that is being returned by the method is what's registered with the system, and it's what clients and other service will see when they ask for the service's address.
trans-unit.target: The reason for this is that this address that is being returned by the method is what's registered with the system, and it's what clients and other service will see when they ask for the service's address.

trans-unit.source: For clients to correctly connect to it, they need an actual IP or FQDN in the address.
trans-unit.target: For clients to correctly connect to it, they need an actual IP or FQDN in the address.

trans-unit.source: Note that this references the Startup class that was passed in to the OwinCommunicationListener in the constructor.
trans-unit.target: Note that this references the Startup class that was passed in to the OwinCommunicationListener in the constructor.

trans-unit.source: This Startup instance is used by the web server to bootstrap the Web API application.
trans-unit.target: This Startup instance is used by the web server to bootstrap the Web API application.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceEventSource.Current.Message() line will appear in the diagnostics event window later when you run the application to let you know the web server has started successfully.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceEventSource.Current.Message() line will appear in the diagnostics event window later when you run the application to let you know the web server has started successfully.

trans-unit.source: Finally, implement both CloseAsync and Abort to stop the web server.
trans-unit.target: Finally, implement both CloseAsync and Abort to stop the web server.

trans-unit.source: The web server can be stopped by disposing the server handle that was created during OpenAsync.
trans-unit.target: The web server can be stopped by disposing the server handle that was created during OpenAsync.

trans-unit.source: In this example implementation, both CloseAsync and Abort simply stop the web server.
trans-unit.target: In this example implementation, both CloseAsync and Abort simply stop the web server.

trans-unit.source: You may opt to perform a more gracefully coordinated shut down of the web server in CloseAsync; for example, waiting for in-flight requests to complete before returning.
trans-unit.target: You may opt to perform a more gracefully coordinated shut down of the web server in CloseAsync; for example, waiting for in-flight requests to complete before returning.

trans-unit.source: You're now ready to create and return an instance of OwinCommunicationListener to start the web server.
trans-unit.target: You're now ready to create and return an instance of OwinCommunicationListener to start the web server.

trans-unit.source: Back in the Service class (Service.cs), override the CreateCommunicationListener() method:
trans-unit.target: Back in the Service class (Service.cs), override the CreateCommunicationListener() method:

trans-unit.source: This is where the Web API application and the OWIN host finally meet: The host (OwinCommunicationListener) is given an instance of the application (Web API via Startup), and Service Fabric manages its lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: This is where the Web API application and the OWIN host finally meet: The host (OwinCommunicationListener) is given an instance of the application (Web API via Startup), and Service Fabric manages its lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: This same pattern can typically be followed with any communication stack.
trans-unit.target: This same pattern can typically be followed with any communication stack.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you don't need to do anything in the RunAsync() method, so that override can simply be removed.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you don't need to do anything in the RunAsync() method, so that override can simply be removed.

trans-unit.source: The final Service implementation should be very simple, as it only needs to create the communication listener:
trans-unit.target: The final Service implementation should be very simple, as it only needs to create the communication listener:

trans-unit.source: And the complete OwinCommunicationListener class:
trans-unit.target: And the complete OwinCommunicationListener class:

trans-unit.source: With all the pieces in place, your project should now look like a typical Web API application with the Reliable Services API entry points and an OWIN host:
trans-unit.target: With all the pieces in place, your project should now look like a typical Web API application with the Reliable Services API entry points and an OWIN host:

trans-unit.source: If you haven't done so, <linkText>set up your development environment</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't done so, <linkText>set up your development environment</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can now build and deploy your service.
trans-unit.target: You can now build and deploy your service.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 in Visual Studio to build and deploy the application.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 in Visual Studio to build and deploy the application.

trans-unit.source: In the Diagnostics Events window, you should see a message indicating the web server opened on http://localhost:80/api
trans-unit.target: In the Diagnostics Events window, you should see a message indicating the web server opened on http://localhost:80/api

trans-unit.source: If the port is already be open by another process on your machine, you may see an error here indicating the listener couldn't be opened.
trans-unit.target: If the port is already be open by another process on your machine, you may see an error here indicating the listener couldn't be opened.

trans-unit.source: If that's the case, try using a different port in the Endpoint configuration in ServiceManifest.xml.
trans-unit.target: If that's the case, try using a different port in the Endpoint configuration in ServiceManifest.xml.

trans-unit.source: Once the service is running, open a browser and navigate to <linkText>http://localhost/api</linkText><title></title> to test it out.
trans-unit.target: Once the service is running, open a browser and navigate to <linkText>http://localhost/api</linkText><title></title> to test it out.

trans-unit.source: Scaling out stateless web apps typically means adding more machines and spinning up the web app on them.
trans-unit.target: Scaling out stateless web apps typically means adding more machines and spinning up the web app on them.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric's orchestration engine can do this for you whenever new nodes are added to a cluster.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric's orchestration engine can do this for you whenever new nodes are added to a cluster.

trans-unit.source: When creating instances of a stateless service, you can specify the number of instances you want to create.
trans-unit.target: When creating instances of a stateless service, you can specify the number of instances you want to create.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric will place that number of instances on nodes in the cluster accordingly, making sure not to create more than one instance on any one node.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric will place that number of instances on nodes in the cluster accordingly, making sure not to create more than one instance on any one node.

trans-unit.source: You can also instruct Service Fabric to always create an instance on every node by specifying "-1" for the instance count.
trans-unit.target: You can also instruct Service Fabric to always create an instance on every node by specifying "-1" for the instance count.

trans-unit.source: This guarantees that whenever you add nodes to scale out your cluster, an instance of your stateless service will be created on the new nodes.
trans-unit.target: This guarantees that whenever you add nodes to scale out your cluster, an instance of your stateless service will be created on the new nodes.

trans-unit.source: This value is a property of the service instance, so it is set when creating a service instance either through PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: This value is a property of the service instance, so it is set when creating a service instance either through PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: Or when defining a default service in a Visual Studio Stateless Service project:
trans-unit.target: Or when defining a default service in a Visual Studio Stateless Service project:

trans-unit.source: For more information on creating application and service instances, see <linkText>how to deploy and remove applications</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on creating application and service instances, see <linkText>how to deploy and remove applications</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In ASP.NET 5, the concept and programming model of separating the application from the host in web applications remains the same.
trans-unit.target: In ASP.NET 5, the concept and programming model of separating the application from the host in web applications remains the same.

trans-unit.source: It can also be applied to other forms of communication.
trans-unit.target: It can also be applied to other forms of communication.

trans-unit.source: In addition, although the host may differ in ASP.NET 5, the Web API application layer remains the same, which is where the bulk of application logic actually lives.
trans-unit.target: In addition, although the host may differ in ASP.NET 5, the Web API application layer remains the same, which is where the bulk of application logic actually lives.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Debugging your Service Fabric Application in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Debugging your Service Fabric Application in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>
